title: Worlds First ELECTRIC Snowmobile - 120 Horsepower!
description: Can electric power take on the Freezing Temperatures?! Today, in below freezing weather, its time to test out the worlds first Electric Snow machine. Get more info on Taiga Motors here:  Use code 'JerryRig' for a $500 dollar discount. Personally I'm a huge fan of this new powerfully silent maintenance free revolution. Now we just have to get my wife and my wallet on board as well.   See the Taiga Factory in action HERE:   Get my Shirts and Razor Knife here!    Anker is named as the Official Charging Partner of JerryRigEverything:    *Follow me for updates!* Instagram:  Facebook:  Twitter:   LARGE tool kit:  Travel Tool Kit:  Mega Tool Kit:  Plastic Pry tools:  Metal phone opening tool:  Replacement phone parts:   The camera I used to film this video:  The Lens I used for this video:  Wide angle lens:  And this Metabones adapter:  This is the drone I use:   TO SEND ME STUFF: See my P.O. Box on my 'About page':   JerryRigEverything assumes no liability for property damage or injury incurred as a result of any of the information contained in this video.  JerryRigEverything recommends safe practices when working with power tools, automotive lifts, lifting tools, jack stands, electrical equipment, blunt instruments, chemicals, lubricants, expensive electronics, or any other tools or equipment seen or implied in this video.  Due to factors beyond the control of JerryRigEverything, no information contained in this video shall create any express or implied warranty or guarantee of any particular result.  Any injury, damage or loss that may result from improper use of these tools, equipment, or the information contained in this video is the sole responsibility of the user and not JerryRigEverything. Only attempt your own repairs if you can accept personal responsibility for the results, whether they are good or bad.
transcript: Right now it is 1 degree, super cold, and behind me is the World's First Modern Electric Snowmobile. It's taking battery power places it's never been before. Right now we are in Vermont snuggled super close up to Canada so you know it's cold. And you're probably asking yourself, 'Hey Jerry, how do electric batteries handle in such cold weather?' And that's a fantastic question. This video is sponsored by Audible. Let's get started. [Intro] So I'm no expert on snow machines, but my family is from Wyoming and so I was around them a lot growing up. And infallibly every year it is a fiasco trying to get them started and going. Cold metal and icy gasoline aren't the best combination. There's a myth that goes 'to be a snowmobiler you have to also be a mechanic.' But that myth is not true with this fully electric snowmobile. Electric snowmobiles just like electric cars have virtually no maintenance. There's no oil, no fuel injectors, no CVT. Plus, with an electric motor and electric batteries, this has an instant 170 newton meters of torque. And while the no maintenance is pretty awesome, I want to hear what it sounds like. Let's put the key in. Any background noise you might hear are from the gas powered sleds with all that smoke over there. The way the snowmobile turns on is with this guy, an RFID magnet that gets put into place here, then we press the green button, listen close. The clicks are the contactors closing just like what happens with my Hummer. And just like that the machine is on. We can still hear the birds and nature and we are ready to go. So I promise I didn't plan this but a bunch of non-electric snowmobiles just showed up and now we gotta go find somewhere else to film. But I forgot about the exhaust fumes that come off of these things as well. It's a totally different experience. Let's go somewhere we can be alone. That escalated quickly. [Music playing] That thing is so fast, and one thing that I was not ready for is that this actually has regen, so as you're slowing down it's taking the energy of the sled moving forward and putting power back into the batteries. On the right side of the display you can see how much power we're using while accelerating or slowing down. One of the perks of electric vehicles, cars and this snowmobile now, is that you'll end up with more power at the bottom of the hill than you had when you started up at the top. The sled we're on today is called the Nomad. Taiga has 3 different models of snowmobiles. There's the Echo, the Nomad, and the Atlas. This is the utility version that can tow 1,100 pounds as it's going through snow. The motor and battery packs are proprietary to Taiga. They are using the pouch-style cells. It's a 23 kilowatt hour battery pack which will get you around 60 miles of range. You might be curious how much it weighs. I would say right around 750 pounds give or take a few. And while the motor and battery might be proprietary, the skis on the front and the tracks on the back are off the shelf. So if those ever need replacing it's super easy to find parts. And as far as charging goes, it uses a standard J1772 outlet, the exact same one I have on my Hummer. The charge port is located exactly where the fill nozzle would be on a regular snowmobile and it gives you a couple different options. One, you can charge it up with just your normal standard wall outlet which takes about 12 hours or so. The second option is you can pull up to an electric vehicle charger, whether it's installed in your garage, or you know, where electric cars go to charge. That same plug can charge us up in about 3 or 4 hours. But, if you find one of the DC fast charging plugs, these two little circles down at the bottom, means you can go from 0-80% in just 30 minutes of charging. And like I said earlier that gets you to about 60 miles of range. My first impressions driving this thing is I was just surprised at how easy it was to move and how non...I guess threatening is the word...just getting on there's nothing to rev up. You just press the throttle and it's instant acceleration, instant torque and it's just quiet, which I'm a huge fan of. Also, since it's 1 degree right now, you might think that the batteries would struggle in cold weather because lithium batteries like to be in the same temperature range as humans do and it's super cold right now. Taiga has developed a special thermal management system that warms up the coolant and puts it through the batteries to keep them at that optimal temperature. And as you're powering through the powder, obviously the motor and batteries are going to heat up and it can use the snow to cool down a radiator to bring them back down to the temperature that batteries want to be in. If we take a look underneath the sled right here, the 15 inch wide track tosses snow up onto the radiator which cools down the motor and the battery pack. It's also interesting to see that these are metal spikes embedded into the tracks, and the studs, I assume, give it more grip on ice. The battery enclosure is also made of full carbon fiber. So let me walk you through how to operate this thing. There are no pedals on the sides like you would find on a motorcycle. All the controls happen right here at the hands. Right here is how we adjust the different modes. We have range mode off to the left, and sport mode off to the right. And then here's how we adjust the regen. We have low and high. And obviously we have the brakes here, throttle here, kill switch here, and we saw the key in the on button before. It's super simple to use and all of the controls are in the hands. The snowmobiles are passing up over here on the side. You can hear these guys from a mile away. One thing I think is interesting and one aspect these could be really used for is search and rescue because you can go up into the woods searching for someone and still hear them at the same time, where if you're riding one of these other sleds, there's no way. Taiga is starting deliveries of these snowmobiles this year, the fall of 2022. I'll leave a link down in the description if you want to learn more. Personally I'm a fan of where this powerful, quiet, maintenance-free revolution is headed. Apparently Taiga has an electric jet ski as well, so let me know if you want to see that in action. Before coming out here my wife told me that I was not allowed to buy one, but I'm hoping when I get back I can renegotiate with her. Help me persuade her in the comments down below. Leave any questions down there as well, I'll try to answer them. Come hang out with me on Instagram and Twitter. And thanks a ton for watching. I'll see you around.
